messages: c73fe5bfcee08da571e60e69dbbb9908 (22:12): howdy. I can't seem to create ElementTrees with html5lib 0.90: http://pastebin.com/m298aa482
0ed43c3891652e44aeb99632195e3c4b (22:27): is it outside the scope of html5 to establish how user agents should treat a content body when issued a 404?
0ed43c3891652e44aeb99632195e3c4b (22:28): seems like more of an http issue but thought i'd check
a1fbe72f47651e50181e743dc550aeee (22:30): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: How come this doesn't say that the default text alignment for <th> is center? http://dev.w3.org/html5/markup/th.html#th
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:30): Sounds like HTTP.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (22:33): a1fbe72f47651e50181e743dc550aeee: MikeSmithX is editor for that document
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:33): a1fbe72f47651e50181e743dc550aeee: dunno, i didn't write that document
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (22:57): http://www.zazzle.com/cssquirrel
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:58): The funny part is that it's probably grounds for a libel suit in England
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:01): Not if it's true
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:01): Wait, you need grounds for a libel suit in England these days?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:02): That's an awesome T-shirt.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:02): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I don't think truth is relevant
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:02): As long as feelings are hurt
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:03): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_defamation_law#Justification - "A claim of defamation is defeated if the defendant proves that the statement was true."
132ea029b178e3c6d3a3aa4521ea24a5 (23:05): right, but the burden of proof is reversed
132ea029b178e3c6d3a3aa4521ea24a5 (23:06): waits for libel prosecutors to discover G??del's theorem
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:07): That's libelous to say, 132ea029b178e3c6d3a3aa4521ea24a5
375764498e9bd499799a5e7b5bf8c5c6 (23:27): I'd love a libel suit
375764498e9bd499799a5e7b5bf8c5c6 (23:27): with a libel waistcoat and libel trousers
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (23:32): haha

d6d480b9c802795eacca0736f96e1487 (23:34): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: according to http://dev.w3.org/html5/status/issue-status.html it looks like the deadline for ISSUE-4 change proposals as past
b1b5726c973cb9e906ce1b5bb246147f (23:35): 0ed43c3891652e44aeb99632195e3c4b: not if the missing resource is a stylesheet, script, image, video...
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:51): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Just watched Hot Fuzz on your recommendation (a while back).  Good movie!

0ed43c3891652e44aeb99632195e3c4b (23:54): b1b5726c973cb9e906ce1b5bb246147f: i have not explicitly tested for stylesheets, script, etc. i stumbled over an apache  configuration that implements the ErrorDocument directive to send 404s to index.xml which in turn issues a meta redirect to a script.  FF3.5, Safari 4, and Opera 10 follow the redirect where IE8 and Chrome 4 ignore it. I figured I would raise this behavior here so folks are aware of it. It may or may not be a behavior worth standardizing on.
0ed43c3891652e44aeb99632195e3c4b (23:55): all browers follow the redirect when visiting index.html directly
b1b5726c973cb9e906ce1b5bb246147f (23:56): meta refresh, you mean?
375764498e9bd499799a5e7b5bf8c5c6 (00:01): following meta refreshes is often a preference in a browser
375764498e9bd499799a5e7b5bf8c5c6 (00:02): as an author, using a meta refresh is a bit amateur

0ed43c3891652e44aeb99632195e3c4b (00:06): 375764498e9bd499799a5e7b5bf8c5c6: I agree, but thats not the reason i'm mentioning this. The meta refresh is just an example of the UA rendering the entity body when encountering a 404.
375764498e9bd499799a5e7b5bf8c5c6 (00:07): 0ed43c3891652e44aeb99632195e3c4b: my mistake, I'm in a lot of webdev support channels, I sometimes forget I'm also in this one when flicking through

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:19): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: for the websocket nonce thing... i'm trying to come up with something equally hard to predict or fake, but which can be done trivially (e.g. without implementing MD5 or using a library). What do you think of the client sending 16 bytes of noise, and the server return 8 bytes of noise consisting of the first 8 bytes from the client xored with the second 8 bytes?
a1fbe72f47651e50181e743dc550aeee (00:20): MikeSmithX: How come this doesn't say that the default text alignment for <th> is center? http://dev.w3.org/html5/markup/th.html#th
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:21): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: Hmm, did I actually recommend it?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:21): Pretty sure.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:21): I thought I usually just mention things without actually giving an opinion because my opinion might be wrong and that would be embarrassing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:24): clearly you are in fact wrong about not giving an opinion
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:25): Shouldn't have given that opinion, I guess.

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:30): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: the 2008 doctype data seems a bit dated; i found that the 116 doctypes were all gone by now, and looking further at the others doesn't give much fruit either
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:33): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: could you maybe do a new query for: (?i)<!doctype\s*html\s+public\s*("[^"]*"|'[^']*')\s*[^"'>]
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:51): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: that doesn't convey the origin at all
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:52): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: or include anything that specifically indicates WebSocket and not some other protocol

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:54): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: the client could use a one-time pad to encrypt the request handshake, but you really want the server to decrypt and then repack what it got
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:54): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: if you're basing this on abarth's concept
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:06): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: Do you want just a list of URLs, or also the matching excerpts?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:07): (The latter is harder because my multi-line grep program only outputs URLs)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (01:07): urls is fine
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:08): Incidentally, I believe that regexp won't work because " " matches "\s*[^"'>]"
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (01:08): oh forgot \s in there
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:09): I think \s*+[^"'>] ought to work
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:09): using Java's possessive quantifiers
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (01:09): i don't know what that means, but if it's equivalent then i guess it's good
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:10): It means it'll match as much of \s as possible, and not back off
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:10): (so there will never be any whitespace left for the [...] to match)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:12): starts grepping
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:19): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: http://philip.html5.org/data/doctype-with-bogus-after-pub-id.txt
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:23): Yay!  Just mounted by first NFS share.
